docs.lead_paragraph: and American exercise enthusiasts - go out in the noonday sun on days when heat and humidity turn the outdoors into a steam bath. For some the result of their exertion is a heat-induced illness that, in its most severe form, can be fatal. But you need not abandon your exercise program just because it's hot. You can't do anything about the weather, so as the dog days of summer take hold, it pays to know how to tailor your activities to suit what the season delivers. Sports experts say that the recommended adjustments not only will enhance the comfort and healthfulness of your activity but may also improve your performance. To appreciate the importance of their advice it helps to know what happens to the human body when it gets hot. To keep body proteins from ''cooking'' like an egg white, inner body temperature must stay under 107 degrees Fahrenheit. Ordinary metabolic activities that take place even while you sleep produce heat, much as a furnace would. The heat produced by intense muscle activity is comparable to that of a blast furnace. Since it raises body temperature, it must be dissipated.

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is a health problem among Suffolk County's teen- agers that threatens to approach epidemic proportions. Yet the reaction of many of the county's leaders is to sermonize on its causes and then withhold help that might have been available. Recent statistics show that Suffolk County has the highest rate of teen- age pregnancy in the state. From 1971 to 1981, it rose 85 percent. In 1982, 32 out of every 1,000 girls between 10 and 19 became pregnant, an increase of 13 percent over the previous year. The increase in the state for the same period was 3 percent. In addition, during the same decade, the abortion rate among teen-agers in the county rose 146 percent, and in 1982 two- thirds of the teen-age pregnancies in Suffolk ended in abortion.
